SENT.plain: A previously healthy 10-week-old infant presented with isolated unilateral facial nerve paralysis which progressed to bilateral paralysis over a 2-week period
Evaluation including MRI and CT of the brain and facial nerve, CSF evaluation and EMG yielded no diagnosis
A single F508 gene mutation on the newborn screen prompted sweat chloride testing which confirmed a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis
On measurement of fat-soluble vitamins, levels of vitamin A were approximately 10% of the lower normal range, in the absence of objective evidence of pseudotumor cerebri
This case emphasizes an important association between hypovitaminosis A, cystic fibrosis and facial nerve palsy
